canonical_explanation.text: Animal fibres include wool and silk. Wool is obtained from the fleece (hair) of sheep, goats, yaks, camels, and llamas. The processing of wool involves shearing, scouring, sorting, dyeing, spinning, and weaving. Workers who sort wool may contract sorter's disease caused by anthrax bacteria present in the fleece. Silk is obtained from the cocoon of the silk moth. The rearing of silkworms for obtaining silk is called sericulture. The life cycle of a silk moth includes egg, larva (silkworm/caterpillar), pupa (cocoon), and adult moth. The process of taking out silk fibres from the cocoon is called reeling. Different types of silk include mulberry silk, tassar silk, eri silk, and mooga silk.
rules: Wool and silk are animal fibres.
Wool is obtained from the hair (fleece) of animals like sheep, goat, yak, camel, and llama.
Processing of wool: shearing → scouring → sorting → dyeing → spinning → weaving.
Shearing is the removal of fleece from the animal's body.
Scouring is washing the fleece to remove grease and dirt.
Sorter's disease is caused by anthrax bacteria found in animal fleece.
Silk is obtained from the cocoon of the silk moth.
Sericulture is the rearing of silkworms to obtain silk.
Life cycle of silk moth: egg → larva (caterpillar) → pupa (cocoon) → adult moth.
Reeling is the process of unwinding silk threads from cocoons.

questions.question_text: Wool is obtained from the fleece of which animal?
questions.explanation_correct: Wool is primarily obtained from the fleece (hair) of sheep. The thick coat of hair on a sheep's body is called fleece, which is sheared off and processed to make wool.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cows (A), hens (C), and fish (D) do not provide wool. Sheep have a thick fleece that is the primary source of wool fibres.

questions.question_text: The first step in processing wool from sheep is:
questions.explanation_correct: Shearing is the first step in processing wool. It involves removing the fleece (thick coat of hair) from the sheep's body using a shearing machine or blade. This is done in spring when the sheep no longer need their warm coat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scouring (A), sorting (B), and dyeing (D) are later steps in wool processing. The sequence is: shearing → scouring → sorting → dyeing → spinning → weaving.

questions.question_text: What is scouring in the processing of wool?

options.text: Cutting the fleece from the sheep
Washing the fleece to remove grease and dirt

questions.explanation_correct: Scouring is the process of washing the sheared fleece in tanks to remove grease, dirt, and other impurities. It is the second step in wool processing after shearing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cutting the fleece is called shearing (A). Colouring is dyeing (C). Spinning (D) is converting fibres into yarn. Scouring specifically refers to the washing step.

questions.question_text: Sorter's disease is caused by:

options.text: A virus found in silk cocoons
A fungus found on cotton plants

questions.explanation_correct: Sorter's disease is caused by a bacterium called Bacillus anthracis (anthrax) that can be present in animal fleece. People who sort wool are at risk of inhaling these bacteria, leading to a serious infection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not caused by a virus in silk cocoons (A), a fungus on cotton (C), or a wool allergy (D). Sorter's disease is specifically an anthrax infection contracted from handling contaminated animal fleece.

questions.question_text: What is sericulture?

options.text: Rearing of silkworms to obtain silk

questions.explanation_correct: Sericulture is the practice of rearing silkworms (silk moth larvae) for the purpose of producing silk. It involves cultivating mulberry plants, raising silkworms, and harvesting silk from their cocoons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rearing sheep for wool (A) is called sheep husbandry. Growing cotton (C) is agriculture. Making synthetic fibres (D) is a manufacturing process. Sericulture specifically refers to silk production through silkworm rearing.

questions.question_text: Silk fibre is obtained from which part of the silk moth's life cycle?
questions.explanation_correct: Silk fibre is obtained from the cocoon, which is spun by the silkworm (larva) when it enters the pupa stage. The cocoon is made of a single continuous silk thread that can be unwound.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silk is not obtained from the egg (A), the larva itself (B), or the adult moth (D). The silk thread comes from the cocoon, which the larva spins around itself before becoming a pupa.

questions.question_text: The process of taking out silk threads from the cocoon is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Reeling is the process of unwinding or drawing out silk threads from the cocoon. The cocoons are first placed in hot water to soften the silk, and then the threads are carefully pulled out.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Shearing (A) is removing fleece from sheep. Scouring (C) is washing fleece. Spinning (D) is twisting fibres into yarn. Reeling specifically refers to extracting silk threads from cocoons.

questions.question_text: Which of the following animals does NOT yield wool?
questions.explanation_correct: Parrots are birds and do not provide wool fibre. Wool-yielding animals include sheep, goats, yaks, camels, llamas, and alpacas — all of which have thick hair that can be processed into wool.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Yaks (A), camels (B), and llamas (D) all have thick hair that can be used to make wool. Only the parrot (C), being a bird with feathers instead of hair, does not yield wool.

questions.question_text: The most common type of silk is:
questions.explanation_correct: Mulberry silk is the most common and widely produced type of silk. It is obtained from the cocoon of Bombyx mori silkworms that feed on mulberry leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While tassar (A), eri (C), and mooga (D) are also types of silk, mulberry silk is the most commonly produced, accounting for the majority of world silk production.

questions.question_text: What is the correct order of steps in processing wool?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of wool processing is: Shearing (cutting fleece) → Scouring (washing) → Sorting (separating by quality) → Dyeing (colouring). After these steps, the wool is spun into yarn and woven into fabric.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The process must begin with shearing (removing the fleece) before any other step can be done. After shearing, the fleece is washed (scoured), then sorted by quality, then dyed.

questions.question_text: Wool is a plant fibre.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Wool is an animal fibre, not a plant fibre. It is obtained from the hair (fleece) of animals such as sheep, goats, yaks, and camels. Cotton and jute are examples of plant fibres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wool is not a plant fibre — it is an animal fibre obtained from the fleece of animals like sheep. Plant fibres include cotton and jute.

questions.question_text: Silk is obtained from the cocoon of the silk moth.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Silk fibre is obtained from the cocoon spun by the silkworm (larva of the silk moth). The cocoon is made of a continuous silk thread that is unwound through reeling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The silk moth larva (silkworm) spins a cocoon made of silk fibre around itself. This cocoon is harvested and the silk thread is extracted through reeling.

questions.question_text: Angora wool is obtained from angora goats.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Angora wool is obtained from angora goats. The soft, fine hair of angora goats is used to make luxurious angora wool fabrics. (Note: Angora fibre also comes from angora rabbits.)
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Angora goats produce a type of wool known as mohair or angora wool. These goats have soft, fine hair that is highly valued in the textile industry.

questions.question_text: The removal of fleece from the body of a sheep is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Shearing is the process of cutting off the thick coat of hair (fleece) from the sheep's body. It is usually done in spring when the sheep no longer need the warm coat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'shearing'. This is the first step in wool processing where the fleece is removed from the sheep using a shearing machine or hand blades.

questions.question_text: The rearing of silkworms for obtaining silk is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Sericulture is the practice of rearing silkworms to produce silk. It involves growing mulberry plants for the silkworms to feed on, and managing the silkworm lifecycle to harvest silk from their cocoons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'sericulture'. This is the scientific term for the practice of breeding and raising silkworms for silk production. It has been practised for thousands of years.

questions.question_text: The process of making yarn from wool fibres is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Spinning is the process of twisting and drawing out fibres to form yarn or thread. The sorted and dyed wool fibres are spun into yarn, which is then used for weaving or knitting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'spinning'. After the wool fibres are sorted and dyed, they are spun (twisted together) to form continuous yarn that can be woven into fabric.

questions.question_text: Why is shearing of sheep usually done in summer or spring?

options.text: Because sheep grow more wool in summer
Because sheep can survive without their warm fleece in warmer months
Because wool is of better quality in summer
Because the fleece is easier to wash in summer

questions.explanation_correct: Shearing is done in summer or spring because the warm weather means sheep can survive comfortably without their thick fleece coat. If shearing were done in winter, the sheep would be exposed to cold and could fall ill.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wool growth is not specifically greater in summer (A). Quality does not depend on season (C). Washing ease (D) is not the determining factor. The main reason is that sheep need their fleece for warmth in winter.

questions.question_text: In sericulture, silkworms are fed leaves of which plant?
questions.explanation_correct: Silkworms (Bombyx mori) feed exclusively on mulberry leaves. That is why the most common type of silk is called mulberry silk. Sericulture farms grow mulberry trees specifically to feed the silkworms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silkworms do not feed on neem (A), mango (C), or tulsi (D) leaves. Mulberry (B) leaves are the primary food for silkworms, and this is why silk farms cultivate mulberry plants.

questions.question_text: The correct order of the life cycle of a silk moth is:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct life cycle of a silk moth is: Egg → Larva (caterpillar/silkworm) → Pupa (inside the cocoon) → Adult moth. The silk is harvested at the cocoon (pupa) stage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The life cycle must begin with the egg and follow a specific sequence. The larva (caterpillar) hatches from the egg, then spins a cocoon and becomes a pupa, and finally emerges as an adult moth.

questions.question_text: Before reeling silk from cocoons, the cocoons are placed in hot water. Why?

options.text: To kill the bacteria on the cocoon
To soften the silk fibres and loosen the thread

questions.explanation_correct: Cocoons are placed in hot water to soften the gummy substance (sericin) that holds the silk fibres together. This makes it easier to unwind and reel the silk thread from the cocoon in one continuous strand.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The purpose is not to kill bacteria (A), dye the silk (C), or enlarge the cocoon (D). Hot water softens the sericin (natural gum) so the silk thread can be easily unwound from the cocoon.

questions.question_text: Pashmina shawls are famous for being extremely warm and soft. The wool for pashmina comes from:
questions.explanation_correct: Pashmina wool comes from the Changthangi goat (also called the Pashmina goat) found in the high-altitude regions of Ladakh. The fine, soft undercoat of these goats is used to make the famous Pashmina shawls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Common sheep (A) produce regular wool. Camel (C) produces camel hair wool. Silkworm (D) produces silk, not wool. Pashmina specifically comes from the Changthangi goat of Ladakh.

questions.question_text: A wool sorter has developed a fever and body aches after working with raw fleece. The likely cause is:

options.text: Common cold from the cold fleece
Sorter's disease caused by anthrax bacteria in the fleece

questions.explanation_correct: The symptoms suggest sorter's disease, which is caused by anthrax bacteria (Bacillus anthracis) present in raw animal fleece. Workers who handle and sort raw wool can inhale these bacteria, leading to infection.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Common cold from cold fleece (A) is unlikely. While wool allergy (B) exists, the described symptoms are more consistent with infection. Exhaustion (D) alone would not cause fever. Sorter's disease from anthrax bacteria is the most likely cause.

questions.question_text: Mooga silk is a special variety of silk produced mainly in:
questions.explanation_correct: Mooga silk is a golden-yellow variety of silk produced mainly in Assam, India. It is highly valued for its natural golden colour and durability. The mooga silkworm feeds on soalu and som leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Karnataka (A) is known for mulberry silk, mooga silk is specifically associated with Assam (C). Kerala (B) and Rajasthan (D) are not major producers of mooga silk.

questions.question_text: Why is wool naturally warm?

options.text: Because it generates heat on its own
Because the crimped fibres trap air, which acts as an insulator
Because it absorbs heat from the sun
Because it is made of synthetic materials

questions.explanation_correct: Wool fibres are naturally crimped (wavy), which creates tiny air pockets between the fibres. Air is a poor conductor of heat and acts as an insulator, trapping body heat and keeping the wearer warm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Wool does not generate heat (A) or absorb special heat from the sun (C). It is a natural fibre, not synthetic (D). Its warmth comes from air trapped between the crimped fibres acting as insulation.

questions.question_text: During silk production, cocoons are boiled or treated with steam. What happens to the pupa inside?

options.text: The pupa escapes from the cocoon
The pupa transforms into a moth

questions.explanation_correct: The cocoons are boiled or steamed to kill the pupa inside. If the pupa were allowed to develop into a moth, it would break through the cocoon, cutting the silk thread and making it impossible to reel a continuous fibre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pupa does not escape (A), transform (C), or remain alive (D). It is killed by the boiling water or steam so that the silk thread can be unwound without being broken by an emerging moth.

questions.question_text: Shearing does not hurt the sheep because the fleece is like hair and grows back.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Shearing is similar to getting a haircut — it does not hurt the sheep because the outer part of the hair does not have nerve endings. The fleece grows back after shearing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Just as cutting human hair does not cause pain, shearing does not hurt sheep. The fleece is made of dead cells (like hair) and regrows naturally.

questions.question_text: All types of silk are produced by the same species of silkworm.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. Different types of silk (mulberry, tassar, eri, mooga) are produced by different species of silk moths. Each species feeds on different plants and produces silk with distinct characteristics.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Different types of silk come from different species of silk moths. Mulberry silk comes from Bombyx mori, tassar silk from Antheraea mylitta, eri silk from Samia cynthia ricini, and mooga silk from Antheraea assamensis.

questions.question_text: The process of unwinding silk threads from the cocoon is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Reeling is the process of carefully unwinding the silk thread from the cocoon. The cocoons are first softened in hot water, and then the silk threads are drawn out and wound onto a reel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'reeling'. After cocoons are softened in hot water, the silk fibres are pulled out and wound onto a spool. This unwinding process is called reeling.

questions.question_text: The thick coat of hair on a sheep's body is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The thick coat of hair covering a sheep's body is called fleece. This fleece is sheared off and processed to obtain wool fibres that are used to make woollen fabric.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'fleece'. Fleece refers to the entire coat of wool covering a sheep's body. It is removed during shearing and then processed into wool.

questions.question_text: After sorting, wool fibres of different textures are used for different purposes. Which type is used for making sweaters?

options.text: Fine, soft fibres for making clothing
Very short fibres discarded as waste

questions.explanation_correct: Fine, soft wool fibres are used for making clothing items like sweaters, shawls, and scarves. The sorting step separates fibres by quality — finer fibres go to clothing, while coarser fibres are used for carpets and blankets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Coarse fibres (A) are used for carpets, not sweaters. Short fibres (C) may be discarded. Mixing with synthetics (D) is a separate process. Sweaters are made from the fine, soft fibres selected during sorting.

questions.question_text: Which Indian breed of sheep is known for producing good quality wool?
questions.explanation_correct: Lohi is an Indian breed of sheep known for producing good quality wool. Other Indian wool-producing sheep breeds include Rampur Bushair, Nali, Bakharwal, and Marwari.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Jersey (A) is a breed of cow. Murrah (C) is a breed of buffalo. Sahiwal (D) is a breed of cow. Lohi (B) is the sheep breed among these options.

questions.question_text:
Arrange the following steps of wool processing in the correct order:
(i) Dyeing
(ii) Shearing
(iii) Spinning
(iv) Scouring
(v) Sorting
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order is: Shearing (ii) → Scouring (iv) → Sorting (v) → Dyeing (i) → Spinning (iii). First the fleece is cut, then washed, sorted by quality, dyed to desired colours, and finally spun into yarn.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Scouring cannot come before shearing (B). Sorting should come after scouring, not before (C). Dyeing cannot be the first step (D). The logical sequence starts with shearing and ends with spinning.

questions.question_text: In the silk production process, at which stage is the silk moth killed?

options.text: At the larva stage before cocoon spinning
At the pupa stage inside the cocoon
At the adult moth stage after emerging

questions.explanation_correct: The silk moth is killed at the pupa stage inside the cocoon by boiling the cocoons in water. This is done because if the moth emerges, it would break the continuous silk thread, making it unusable for reeling.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Killing at the egg (A) or larva (B) stage would prevent cocoon formation. Killing at the adult stage (D) would be too late — the moth would have already broken the silk thread. The pupa stage (C) is when the cocoon is intact and the silk can be reeled.

questions.question_text:
Match the following fibres with their source animals:
(i) Pashmina — (a) Alpaca
(ii) Mohair — (b) Changthangi goat
(iii) Alpaca wool — (c) Angora goat
(iv) Cashmere — (d) Cashmere goat

Choose the correct matching:
questions.explanation_correct: Pashmina comes from Changthangi goat (b), Mohair from Angora goat (c), Alpaca wool from Alpaca (a), and Cashmere from Cashmere goat (d).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each fibre type comes from a specific animal breed. Pashmina is from Changthangi goats of Ladakh, Mohair from Angora goats, Alpaca wool from the South American alpaca, and Cashmere from Cashmere goats.

questions.question_text: A student wants to identify whether a fabric is made of silk or synthetic fibre. Which test can help?

options.text: Burn test — silk burns with the smell of burning hair, synthetic melts
Water test — silk dissolves in water, synthetic does not
Colour test — silk is always white, synthetic is coloured
Weight test — silk is always heavier than synthetic

questions.explanation_correct: The burn test is a reliable way to distinguish silk from synthetic fibre. Silk, being a protein fibre, burns with the smell of burning hair and leaves a powdery ash. Synthetic fibres melt, shrink, and may produce a chemical smell.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silk does not dissolve in water (B). Silk is not always white (C) — it can be dyed. Weight alone (D) is not a reliable indicator. The burn test (A) is the standard method to distinguish natural from synthetic fibres.

questions.question_text: Why do sheep have a thick coat of hair?

options.text: To keep them warm by trapping air and providing insulation
To help them swim in water

questions.explanation_correct: Sheep have a thick coat of hair (fleece) primarily for insulation. The hair traps air between the fibres, and since air is a poor conductor of heat, this keeps the sheep warm in cold weather.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The thick coat is not primarily for attractiveness (A), predator protection (B), or swimming (D). Its main function is thermal insulation — keeping the sheep warm in cold climates.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about silk production is INCORRECT?

options.text: Silkworms spin cocoons using silk threads secreted from their salivary glands
Cocoons are boiled to soften them before reeling
A single cocoon can yield about 1000 metres of silk thread
The silkworm survives after the silk is extracted from the cocoon

questions.explanation_correct: The statement that the silkworm survives after silk extraction is incorrect. The cocoons are boiled to kill the pupa inside before reeling. This is necessary to extract the continuous silk thread without it being broken.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silkworms do secrete silk from modified salivary glands (A is correct). Cocoons are boiled before reeling (B is correct). A cocoon can yield significant lengths of thread (C is correct). But the silkworm does not survive — it is killed during boiling (D is incorrect).

questions.question_text: Tassar silk is different from mulberry silk because:

options.text: Tassar silk comes from wild silk moths, mulberry silk from domesticated ones
Tassar silk is made from cotton, mulberry silk from animal fibre
Tassar silk is synthetic, mulberry silk is natural
There is no difference — they are the same

questions.explanation_correct: Tassar silk is obtained from wild silk moths (Antheraea mylitta) that feed on trees like asan and arjun. Mulberry silk comes from the domesticated silkworm Bombyx mori that feeds exclusively on mulberry leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tassar is not from cotton (B) or synthetic (C). They are different (D). The key difference is that tassar silk comes from wild silk moths while mulberry silk comes from domesticated silkworms.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about wool and silk:
(i) Both are natural fibres obtained from animals
(ii) Both are protein fibres
(iii) Both are obtained by the same process
(iv) Both burn with the smell of burning hair

Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii), and (iv) are correct. Both wool and silk are natural animal fibres made of protein, and both burn with the smell of burning hair (protein). Statement (iii) is incorrect — wool is obtained by shearing while silk is obtained by reeling cocoons.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (iii) is incorrect because wool and silk have different extraction processes. Wool comes from shearing animal fleece, while silk comes from reeling cocoons. The other three statements are all correct.

questions.question_text: Weaving is the final step in converting raw wool into woollen fabric.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Weaving (or knitting) is the final step where the spun yarn is interlaced to form fabric. The complete sequence is: shearing → scouring → sorting → dyeing → spinning → weaving.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. After all processing steps (shearing, scouring, sorting, dyeing, and spinning), the yarn is woven on looms to produce woollen fabric, making weaving the final step.

questions.question_text: Silk is the strongest natural fibre.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Silk is considered the strongest natural fibre. A silk thread is stronger than a comparable steel thread of the same diameter. This exceptional strength, combined with its lustre and softness, makes silk highly valued.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Silk has remarkable tensile strength for a natural fibre. Despite being very fine and light, silk threads are incredibly strong — stronger than a comparable thickness of steel.

questions.question_text: The golden-yellow silk produced in Assam from Antheraea assamensis silkworm is called ___ silk.
questions.explanation_correct: Mooga silk is a golden-yellow silk produced exclusively in Assam, India. It is obtained from the Antheraea assamensis silkworm and is known for its natural golden lustre and extreme durability.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'mooga'. Mooga silk is unique to Assam and is the only type of silk with a natural golden-yellow colour. It is highly prized for its beauty and durability.

questions.question_text: The disease that wool sorters may get from handling raw fleece infected with bacteria is called ___ disease.
questions.explanation_correct: Sorter's disease is an occupational hazard for wool sorters. It is caused by the anthrax bacterium (Bacillus anthracis) that may be present in raw animal fleece. The disease can be contracted by inhaling bacterial spores.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'sorter's'. Sorter's disease specifically affects people who sort raw wool and come in contact with anthrax bacteria present in animal fleece.

questions.question_text: A student observes that the silkworm caterpillar eats mulberry leaves voraciously for about 25-30 days. After this, the caterpillar:

options.text: Directly transforms into an adult moth
Starts spinning a cocoon around itself
Lays eggs on the mulberry leaves

questions.explanation_correct: After eating mulberry leaves for 25-30 days, the silkworm caterpillar stops eating and starts spinning a cocoon of silk thread around itself. Inside this cocoon, it transforms into a pupa.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The caterpillar does not directly become a moth (A) — it must go through the pupa stage. Only adult moths lay eggs (C). The caterpillar does not die (D) — it spins a cocoon and enters the pupa stage.

questions.question_text: Which property makes silk a preferred fabric for warm weather clothing?

options.text: Silk is very heavy and keeps the body cool
Silk absorbs moisture and allows air circulation, keeping the body comfortable

questions.explanation_correct: Silk is a breathable fabric that absorbs moisture from the body and allows air to circulate. This keeps the body comfortable in warm weather. Its smooth texture and lightweight nature also contribute to comfort.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Silk is lightweight, not heavy (A). It does not reflect all sunlight (C) or generate cold air (D). Its ability to absorb moisture and allow breathability (B) makes it suitable for warm weather.

questions.question_text: In India, which state is the largest producer of wool?
questions.explanation_correct: Rajasthan is the largest wool-producing state in India. The arid and semi-arid regions of Rajasthan are home to many sheep breeds like Marwari and Chokla that are raised for wool production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kerala (A), Tamil Nadu (C), and West Bengal (D) are not major wool-producing states. Rajasthan (B) leads wool production due to its large sheep population and suitable climate.

questions.question_text: Eri silk is sometimes called 'non-violent silk' because:

options.text: The silkworms are not fed any food
The silk is extracted after the moth naturally emerges from the cocoon
The silk is made from plants, not animals
No chemicals are used in processing

questions.explanation_correct: Eri silk is called 'non-violent silk' or 'peace silk' because the silk moth is allowed to emerge naturally from the cocoon before the silk is harvested. The pupa is not killed, unlike in mulberry silk production.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Eri silkworms are fed (A). Eri silk is an animal fibre (C). The 'non-violent' name refers to the moth not being killed (B), not to chemical processing (D).

questions.question_text: Why are sheep fed a special diet that includes high-quality grain and protein before shearing?

options.text: To improve the quality and growth of their fleece

questions.explanation_correct: Sheep are given a nutritious diet with high-quality grain and protein to improve the quality of their fleece. Good nutrition results in thicker, softer, and higher-quality wool fibres.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diet is not primarily about weight gain (A), ease of shearing (C), or disease prevention (D). Proper nutrition directly affects the quality and quantity of wool the sheep produces.

questions.question_text: Which part of the silk moth produces the silk thread?

options.text: Modified salivary glands (silk glands) of the caterpillar

questions.explanation_correct: The silk thread is produced by modified salivary glands (called silk glands or spinnerets) of the silkworm caterpillar. The caterpillar secretes a liquid protein that hardens into silk thread upon contact with air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The wings (A), legs (C), and eyes (D) of the moth or caterpillar do not produce silk. The silk is secreted from specialised silk glands (modified salivary glands) located in the head region of the caterpillar.

questions.question_text: The Bakharwal breed of sheep is found in which region of India?
questions.explanation_correct: The Bakharwal breed of sheep is found in the Jammu and Kashmir region of India. These sheep are well-adapted to the cold mountainous terrain and produce good quality wool.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While Rajasthan (A) has breeds like Marwari and Chokla, and Gujarat (C) has Patanwadi sheep, the Bakharwal breed is specifically from Jammu and Kashmir (B). Andhra Pradesh (D) has the Nellore breed, which is primarily raised for meat.
